_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ting Procedures, Training, Maintenance, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigations, and Emergency Contingency Plans.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Helena's Orion Facility is a non-responding facility. Helena has coordinated emergency response activities with its local emergency response agency and local fire department.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place, in the past five (5) years because of the ammonia operations at the Orion Facility.

CONCLUSION

The Risk Management Plan implemented by Helena Chemical Company at the Orion Facility complies with the requirements of the Clean Air Act, Section 112(r). The RMP will be updated as the Orion Facility adds, deletes, or changes processes. The Emergency Response Program has been coordinated with the Henry County LEPC and Orion Community Fire Protection District.

NOTE: Sections 4, 5, 6, and 7 of the standard RMP produced by EPA's RMP Submit Program are not applicable to the Orion Facility.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The Helena Orion Facility has submitted this updated electronic RMP in compliance with the provisions of the Clean Air Act 112 (r) as codified by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency at 40 CFR Part 68. Standards codified by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration at 29 CFR 1910.119 are not applicable to the operations at this facility because the facility is operated as a retail operation and is exempt from the OSHA standards.  However, the OSHA standards at 29 CFR 1910.111, Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, are applicable and are included in the Risk Management Program (RMPr) document that is implemented by this Facility.

This electronic submittal provides conservative estimates of the offsite consequences of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia from the Orion Facility located at 2929 N. 1300th Avenue, Orion, IL 61273.  The electronic RMP summarizes the policies and procedures implemented by the Orion Facility to minimize the likelihood of an accident.  The electronic RMP also summarizes the actions that the Orion Facility has taken to ensure that a response to a release will be implemented in a proper and timely manner.

PURPOSE FOR UPDATING RMP

Helena is submitting this as a 5-Year update.  All relevant sections for a Program 2 RMP Facility have been reviewed and/or updated.  The updates are reflected in both the EPA RMP Submit report and the Facility Risk Management Plan Program Document (RMPr).

FACILITY

The Facility is a retail agricultural chemical facility and operates one (1) covered process that includes Storage and Handling of anhydrous ammonia.  Anhydrous ammonia is transported to the Facility via a commercial tanker truck and then transferred to one (1) 18,000-gallon stationary pressure vessel.  The commercial tanker truck operator (Contractor) performs these transfer operations.  

The Facility stores the anhydrous ammonia in the on-site stationary pressure vessel and then transfers the a

nhydrous ammonia from the storage tank to nurse tanks at point of retail sale to the end user (e.g. the farmer).  This Facility owns and operates (16) 1,000-gallon nurse tanks.  Trained Facility personnel perform this operation in accordance with its RMPr accident prevention program.  

OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS

Worst case and alternative case consequence analyses were completed for the single covered process that is operated at this Facility.  The covered process includes anhydrous ammonia Storage and Handling.  The worst case scenario release for the Retail Facility assumes that all the contents in the largest single pressure vessel are released.  For this Facility, the largest vessel is an 18,000-gallon stationary pressure vessel.  The release was modeled as if the vessel was punctured on the side at the ground level. The resulting release of ammonia was modeled as a ground level horizontal jet.

The alternative (or more likely to occur) scenario was completed for the storage and handling covered process as well.  The alternative release for the Storage and Handling assumes a 2-minute release from a ruptured 3-inch transfer hose caused by an impact from a vehicle or some other source on the liquid ammonia transfer hose during a loading or unloading operation.  This alternative scenario involves mitigation equipment including emergency shutoff valves and excess flow valves on the commercial tanker truck and excess flow valve and backflow check valve on the pressure vessel side of the process, and operating procedures that the Facility uses to safeguard ammonia transfer operations.

ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM

The Branch Manager implements the risk management planning process at this Facility.  The Branch Manager is assisted by other Helena staff, as directed.
